div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin July 21st 1915
div1.p: Well, well, and I found this in old Harper’s Weekly, a copy of which was sent out to us here. I read La Vie Parisienne, Le Rire, etc., and it does my heart good to see that American papers are taking somewhat after the French, as testified to by the clipping. I am really socked beyond measure. The measure being so minute, you see.

Ned Salisbury, our Chef de Section left yesterday for Paris to remain eight days. I hope you meet him while he’s down there. He’s an awfully fine chap. He has by the way stumbled into a most wonderful affaire d’amour. If you remind me I’ll tell you about the interesting tale when I see you in September. Has Eleanora Glyum [sp?] beaten forty ways from Sunday. Some chaps are fearfully lucky, or unlucky, it has to be figured in terms of the long run.

I’m happy to day. Ambulance No. 3 is fine. This morning the wounded were brought out to me newly bandaged, a sheet on the stretcher and everything done in good shape. Even the poor blesses seemed happy.

Yesterday. # # At this juncture I had to stop to make a long evacuation. I’ve forgotten what I was going to say after the word yesterday.
Oh, yes, I remember we came in for another warm time of it, and to day it has just stopped, having started at the noon hour. Luck still with us. From hits I think they were trying to get us.

Just heard from Paul. He seems to think you’re a peach. Can’t say as I dispute his taste. I’m waiting to hear his plans before setting the date for my permission. He’s to pass before a committee on August 6th and after that will do some planning. If you have anything on foot aside from working along as you’re doing please let me know as I want to make my schedule accordingly. Paul says you’re working too hard and should take a rest. I wish you would. You might go all to pieces. It isn’t right that you should overtax yourself. You have had no rest for nearly six months. If everyone worked the way you do we would have licked the Boches long ago.
Do keep well and let me know how you’re feeling.

closer.seg: Affectionately. I’d hate to have anyone get that off to me. Doesn’t it bother you?

lg.l: Who she thought had dropped out of the sky—
And the Stork came one day
Marie cried: “What a good girl am I!”
